organic_results.title: Compensation gains in higher education: A reexamination
organic_results.snippet: The Brown and Stone sample of collective bargaining schools is redefined by selecting the collective bargaining unit (which may include several campuses under a common contract) as the unit of observation rather than the individual campus. The application of the Brown and Stone methodology to the redefined sample results in the reaffirmation of the Morgan and Kearney conclusion that collective bargaining in higher education was associated with increased compensation as of the academic year 1974-75. Further testing reveals that the …

publication_info.summary: H Ito, M Masoner - Sociology of education, 1980 - JSTOR

organic_results.title: Compensation Gains in Higher Education: A Reexamination Appraised
organic_results.snippet: In our Economic Inquiry article (1977a) dealing with the impacts of collective bargaining in higher education, we addressed four related questions.(1) Did campuses that unionized have unusual compensation levels prior to collective bargaining?(2) Was unionization associated with un-usual changes in compensation growth across the various ranks?(3) Was unionization associated with changes in interrank salary variation?(4) Was unionization associated with unusual promotion into the terminal ranks? Our analysis was based on data …
